projectDesc.p: To the tune “Spring in the Jade Building”—"Since we parted" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.rdg: To the tune “Spring in the Jade Building”
Since we parted I do not know how far away you are,
Whatever meets my eye looks desolate, so much sadness!
The longer we are apart, the further away you are, the fewer letters sent.

The water is wide and the fish has sunk,
"The fish has sunk" is a common idiom to express a lack of communication where can I ask about you?

The night is late, the wind-blown bamboos strike the autumn rhyme.
This refers to "The Sound of Autumn", a famous song for the erhu, a traditional Chinese string instrument.
In the thousand notes made by tens of thousands of leaves, there is nothing but regret.
Thus I lean onto the lonesome pillow to search for you in my dream,
Yet the dream does not come and the lamp is burnt out.
